summary: METHODS We counted the number of daily searches related to MERS in jeddah, Saudi Arabia from January 1, 2014 to May 16, 2014. we also counted the number of daily searches related to MERS in jeddah, compared them with reported cases during the same period [12]. for the outbreak in jeddah in 2014, for symptomatic cases, the date given for each case represents the date of onset of illness. we calculated the Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient for each daily (Figures 1 and 2) or weekly (Figure 3) comparison of UpToDate MERS searches to reported cases. upToDate MERS signals in jeddah, Saudi Arabia and in the composite of 4 control cities in Saudi Arabia from January 1, 2014 through May 21, 2014. data were selected from January 1, 2014 to February 28, 2014 (considered an outbreak-free period) we calculated the mean and standard deviation for the baseline periods. a P value of.05 was considered statistically significant. upToDate MERS searches in Riyadh showed a correlation to the reported MERS cases. the correlation coefficient was 0.651 (P.00001) during the outbreak period in 2014. the average daily number of UpToDate searches in jeddah was 548. weekly number of UpToDate searches in Riyadh was 15 370. most of these studies have used search engines that are used by the general public. analysis of upToDate search activity could be useful for detecting and monitoring MERS outbreaks in Saudi Arabia. our analysis suggests that UpToDate searches are useful for detecting and monitoring outbreaks of MERS in Saudi Arabia. a previous study showed the utility of UpToDate searches for tracking influenza-like illnesses in the united states.
